title: sg.symplectic geometry - A question about canonical bundle of moduli space of Kahler Einstein metrics
body: Let $\mathcal M$ be a moduli space of Kahler-Einstein metrics with negative Ricci curvatures on pairs $(X,D)$ . Is the canonical bundle of $\mathcal M$ nef? Motivation : If we know the nefness of $\mathcal M$ then due to a result of E.Viehweg, we can prove that $\mathcal M$ is quasi-projective and its compactification $\overline{\mathcal M}$ is projective. Note: Georg Schumacher has another approach for it by uniruled method. sg.symplectic-geometry moduli-spaces kahler-manifolds kahler-einstein-metric projective-varieties Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked Apr 16, 2016 at 8:55 user21574 $\endgroup$ 3 1 $\begingroup$ The very first example is when $X$ is a smooth, genus $2$ curve. Then the moduli space $\mathcal{M}$ is a dense open subset of a rational threefold. What is your definition of "nef" if you allow the canonical bundle of an open subset of a rational threefold to be nef? $\endgroup$ Jason Starr –  Jason Starr 2016-04-16 09:51:19 +00:00 Commented Apr 16, 2016 at 9:51 $\begingroup$ Good example: A line bundle is nef (numerically effective)if the degree of its restriction to every algebraic curve in the variety is non-negative. $\endgroup$ user21574 –  user21574 2016-04-16 09:54:29 +00:00 Commented Apr 16, 2016 at 9:54 $\begingroup$ yes, certainly we must be in deal with an open dense subvariety, for nefness $\endgroup$ user21574 –  user21574 2016-04-16 09:58:13 +00:00 Commented Apr 16, 2016 at 9:58 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
